title: Federal Judge Rejects Tribes’ Move To Halt Construction Of Dakota Access Pipeline
text:

Boasberg also set a date of Feb. 27 for a hearing on a demand from the tribes to order the Army Corps of Engineers to withdraw an easement granted to the pipeline last month that has allowed it to near completion of its 1,170-mile route from North Dakota to Illinois. 
The Standing Rock Sioux and the Cheyenne River Sioux argued Monday that the Missouri River and Lake Oahe are sacred and that the pipeline would “desecrate the Tribe’s sacred waters” and pose “plain irreparable harm.” 
The two tribes said in their filing that the Lakota people believe “the pipeline correlates with a terrible Black Snake prophesied to come into the Lakota homeland and cause destruction.”   
The pipeline company has “the greatest respect for the religious beliefs and traditions of Cheyenne River and the other tribes,” but there is no need for a restraining order, said William Scherman, attorney for Dakota Access LLC. 
Scherman added that the allegation, which had not previously been raised, comes far too late in the process, calling it “a last-ditch desperation throw to the end zone” that ”could not conceivably meet the required showing of irreparable harm needed to support a restraining order or preliminary injunction.” 
More court actions on the pipeline are likely. Dan Hasselman, an attorney for the environmental group Earthjustice and an adviser to the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe, said the tribes will file a broader motion under the National Environmental Policy Act, Clean Water Act and Administrative Process Act. 
“We’re disappointed with today’s ruling denying a temporary restraining order against the Dakota Access Pipeline, but we are not surprised. We know this fight is far from over,” said lead counsel Chase Iron Eyes, a member of the Standing Rock Sioux tribe.
